ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Theoretical predictions of the structural and thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 Laves phase under high pressure

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Key Laboratory of Near Net Forming of Jiangxi Province
National Engineering Research Center of Light Alloys Net Forming
State Key Laboratory of Metal Matrix Composite

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The structural and thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 Laves phase under hydrostatic pressure have been investigated by using a first-principles method based on the density functional theory within the generalized gradient approximation. The calculated equilibrium structural parameters are consistent with the previous experimental and theoretical data. Especially, we study the pressure dependence of the elastic constants, polycrystalline elastic moduli, Poisson’s ratio, elastic anisotropy, and theoretical Vickers hardness of MgZn2. It is found that the pressure plays a significant role in the elastic properties of MgZn2 due to the variations of inter-atomic distance. In addition, the density of states and Mulliken analysis are performed to reveal the bonding characteristics of MgZn2. It is observed that the total density of states exhibits a certain offset with the increase of external pressure. Finally, the dependences of thermodynamic properties on pressure and temperature of MgZn2 Laves phase have been also successfully predicted and analyzed within the quasi-harmonic Debye model for the first time.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: There exist three different types of Laves phase, including the cubic C15 (MgCu2), hexagonal C14 (MgZn2), and double-hexagonal C36 (MgNi2) according to the difference of the particular stacking in the same four-layered structural units [1, 2]. Among these three fundamental structures, the C14-type Laves phase MgZn2 has received interest as a potential candidate for structural application due to its excellent physical and chemical properties [3–6]. Recently, several studies have been performed to reported the structural and thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 compound. Experimentally, the single-crystal elastic constants of MgZn2 in the temperature range from 4.2 to 300 K were determined by McSkimin’s pulse superposition method [7]. Morishita et al. [8] determined the standard Gibbs energy of formation of MgZn2 in the temperature range from near absolute zero to high temperature by calorimetry for the first time. In addition, the structural and thermal stability of primary intermetallic particles in Mg–Zn casting alloy were reported by Gao et al. [9]. Theoretically, Andersson et al. [10] investigated initially the electronic and structural properties of Laves phase MgZn2 of varying chemical disorder with a semilocal exchange-correlation functional in the general gradient approximation. The phase stability, elastic and electronic properties of the MgZn2 compound were calculated from the projector augmented wave method [11, 12]. Chen et al. [13] studied the elastic and thermodynamic properties of AB2 type phases in Mg alloys. They found that the MgZn2 phase exhibits relatively higher structural stability and better plasticity.

Despite substantial efforts in addressing physical properties of MgZn2 compound, most of the previous works were performed under the zero pressure. The pressure dependence of structural and thermodynamic properties of C14-type MgZn2 Laves phase on pressure has not yet been studied by using the theoretical or experimental method. Thus, in this paper, we present a detailed theoretical study of the structural, electronic, and thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 in the pressure of 0 to 50 GPa in the framework of density functional theory (DFT) with the generalized gradient approximation (GGA).

Section1.Heading: Computation details
Section1.Para: All calculations were performed with the CASTEP code [14], based on the DFT using Vanderbilt-type ultrasoft pseudopotentials (USPP) and a plane-wave expansion of the wave functions [15, 16]. The exchange correlation potential was considered by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) in the scheme of Perdew–Burke–Eruzerhof (PBE) [17]. The kinetic cutoff energy for plane waves was set as 400.0 eV. Pseudo-atom calculations were performed for Mg 2p 63s 2 and Zn 3d 104s 2. Brillouin zone sampling was performed by using the Monkhost–Pack scheme [18] with a k-point mesh of 12×12×8 for a unit cell, which makes the separation of the reciprocal space to be less than 0.02 Å−1. The Brodyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno (BFGS) minimization scheme [19] was used to minimize the total energy and internal forces. The elastic constants of MgZn2 were obtained by the stress-strain method [20, 21].

In order to investigate the thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 under elevated temperature and high pressure, the methods of quasi-harmonic Debye model implemented in the Gibbs program were applied. Detailed description of the quasi-harmonic Debye model can be found in [22].

Section2.Heading: Structural properties
Section2.Para:
MgZn2 belongs to the hexagonal structure with a space group P63/mmc (NO. 194). Geometry optimization for MgZn2 has been performed to obtain the equilibrium structural parameters. The equilibrium lattice parameters a, c, and c/a are listed in Table 1. Our obtained results are consistent with the available experimental [4] and other theoretical values [12]. The calculated lattice parameters deviate from the experimental value within 0.2 %. By fitting the third-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state (EOS) [23], the zero pressure bulk modulus B 0 and its pressure derivative B 0’ of MgZn2 are found to be 62.7 GPa and 4.98, respectively, as shown in Table 1. The discrepancy between the experiments and the calculated results can be attributed to the effect of temperature.

To investigate the response of MgZn2 to the external pressure, the relative changes of lattice parameters a and c with increasing pressure are presented in Fig. 1. It is found that the a/a 0 and c/c 0 decreases smoothly with the applied pressure, where a 0 and c 0 is the equilibrium lattice parameters at zero pressure, respectively. The acquired relations can be expressed as:
1
$$\begin{aligned} &{a/a_0=0.995-0.0036P+3.05\times10^{-5}P^2} \end{aligned}$$
2
$$\begin{aligned} &{c/c_{0} = 0.996 - 0.0034P + 2.77 \times 10^{ - 5}P^{2}.} \end{aligned}$$
Fig. 1
The normalized lattice parameters (a/a 0 and c/c 0) and volume V/V 0 as a function of pressure ranges from 0 to 50 GPa for MgZn2 at 0 K. Inset is the equilibrium c/a ratio under different pressures

From Eqs. (1) and (2), it shows that the lattice parameter a changes a little more than c throughout the whole pressure range considered, which indicates that the elastic anisotropy of MgZn2 is weak. Figure 1 also shows the relative change of unit cell volume V/V 0 as a function of the external pressure. As the pressure rises, the change of the distance between atoms is getting smaller due to the mutual repulsion of the atoms, which leads to the difficulty of compression in MgZn2 crystal under compression. Thus, it can be found that the curves of normalized lattice parameters a/a 0, c/c 0 and normalized cell volume V/V 0 become gentler with increasing pressure. It also indicates that MgZn2 is without undergoing a phase transition according to the smooth variations of a/a 0, c/c 0 and V/V 0. The inset of Fig. 1 shows the evolution of the axial ratio c/a as a function of pressure for MgZn2. It can be found that the equilibrium ratio c/a increases from 1.630 at 0 GPa to 1.635 at 30 GPa, with an increase of about 0.32 %. When the pressure is above 30 GPa, the equilibrium ratio c/a decreases from 1.635 to 1.634 at the pressure of 50 GPa, with a decrease of about 0.06 %. The values of ratio c/a under different pressures are all close to the ideal value 1.633 for typical hexagonal close-packed phase. The compressible behavior of MgZn2 is related to the variation of the interatomic distance between the Mg and Zn atoms.

Section2.Heading: Elastic properties
Section2.Para:
The elastic constants can be used to measure the resistance of a crystal to an externally applied stress, and provide information about bonding characteristics near the equilibrium state [24]. Thus, it is essential to investigate the elastic constants in order to understand the mechanical properties of MgZn2. For MgZn2 crystal, there are only five independent elastic constants, i.e., C 11, C 12, C 13, C 33, and C 44, since C 66=(C 11−C 12)/2. The calculated single-crystal elastic constants at the ground states from the present GGA calculation are listed in Table 2. The corresponding mechanical stability criterion of hexagonal crystal is [25]:
3
$$ \begin{aligned} &{C_{11} > 0,\qquad C_{11} - \vert C_{12} \vert > 0,}\\ &{C_{44} > 0,\qquad ( C_{11} + C_{12} )C_{33} - 2C_{13}^{2} > 0.} \end{aligned} $$

As for MgZn2, the calculated elastic constants are consistent with previously experimental [7] and other theoretical values [11]. It can be found that the present results show a better agreement with experimental values than that reported by Chen et al. [13], which is mainly due to the different k-point mesh and the exchange-correlation functional employed. It is found that the calculated elastic constants satisfy the mechanical stability criterion mentioned above, which implies the mechanical stability of MgZn2 at pressure below 50 GPa. It can be seen that the C 11 and C 33 are much larger than the other elastic constants, which indicates that MgZn2 is incompressible under uniaxial stress along a or c axis. Figure 2(a) depicts the variations of the elastic constants of MgZn2 under different pressures. When the bonding strength is enhanced by applying hydrostatic pressure, the five independent elastic constants increase monotonically with increasing pressure. It can be seen that the C 11 and C 33 are more sensitive to the change of pressure than C 12 and C 13, which can be explained by the differences of the compressibility at different directions. Moreover, C 44 associating with the shear deformation resistance increases comparatively slowly with increasing pressure. These results indicate that the enhancement of bonding strength has little influence on the shear deformation resistance.
Fig. 2
The calculated G/B under different pressures for MgZn2. Inset is the pressure dependence of the elastic constants (a) and elastic moduli (b)

The polycrystalline elastic moduli of MgZn2 are determined through using the Voigt–Reuss–Hill (VRH) approximation [26]. The bulk modulus B of a material, reflecting its resistance to volume change, and shear modulus G, describing its resistance to shape change. Young’s modulus E and Poisson’s ν ratio are considered as the important properties for industrial applications, which can be expressed as the following formula [27]:
4
$$\begin{aligned} &{E = \frac{9GB}{3B + G},} \end{aligned}$$
5
$$\begin{aligned} &{\nu = \frac{3B - 2G}{2(3B + B)}.} \end{aligned}$$

The calculated results are shown in Table 3. It can be clearly seen that the obtained results at 0 GPa are in good agreement with the previous theoretical values [11–13]. It should be pointed out that the bulk moduli evaluated from the elastic constants are consistent with that of the Birch–Murnaghan EOS, which indicates that our calculated elastic moduli are robust and reliable. The variations of elastic moduli with increasing pressure are intuitively illustrated in Fig. 2(b). Obviously, the calculated elastic moduli increase with applied pressure, which is similar to the trend of elastic constants. On the other hand, the Poisson’s ratio ν is associated with the volume change during uniaxial deformation, which can provide more information on the characterizations of the bonding forces than elastic constants [28]. The ν with a value of 0.25 and 0.5 is the lower limit and upper limit for central force solids, respectively [29]. In the present case, the acquired value of ν at zero pressure are similar to the results reported by Wu et al. [12] and Chen et al. [13], and they are all larger than the lower limit 0.25, as listed in Table 3, which indicates that MgZn2 crystal are with predominantly central inter-atomic forces. Moreover, it is interesting to find that the Poisson’s ratio decreases first with increasing pressure, and then increases with the increase of pressure when the pressure is above 15 GPa. The value of ν has the range from 0.290 to 0.318 under the pressure range from 0 to 50 GPa, which also indicates that the interatomic forces of MgZn2 are central interatomic forces.

Besides, Pugh [30] introduced the ratio of shear to bulk modulus (G/B), characterized as an indication of brittle versus ductile. A high G/B ratio is associated with brittleness, whereas a low value corresponds to ductility. The critical value which separates ductile and brittle material is about 0.57. The material behaves in a brittle manner if G/B>0.57, otherwise ductile manner. Table 3 shows that the calculated value of the G/B ratio of MgZn2 is consistent with the other reports [12, 13]. The value of G/B is lower than 0.57, which indicates the ductile nature of MgZn2. Figure 2 shows the effect of pressure on the B/G ratio of MgZn2. It is found that the MgZn2 shows two stages of G/B under compression: the G/B ratio first increases below 15 GPa, then a maximum appears at 15 GPa before the G/B ratio decreases above 15 GPa. It means that the pressure will have an important effect on the ductility or brittleness of MgZn2 compound, and favors the ductility of MgZn2 above 15 GPa.

The ratio between linear compressibility coefficients k
c /k
a can evaluate the elastic anisotropy of materials [31]. For hexagonal crystals, k
c /k
a can be expressed as follows:
6
$$ k_{c}/k_{a} = ( C_{11} + C_{12} - 2C_{13} )/ ( C_{33} - C_{13} ). $$

For an isotropic crystal, k
c /k
a is equal to 1, while any deviation from 1 indicates the degree of the elastic anisotropy. The elastic anisotropies of MgZn2 at various pressures are listed in Table 2. The k
c /k
a of MgZn2 at zero pressure is 0.920, which indicates that the MgZn2 exhibits a little anisotropic elasticity. When the pressure is increased to 20 GPa, MgZn2 is approximately isotropic for elasticity. It can be seen that the elastic anisotropy of MgZn2 increases with the change of pressure. This result suggests that the elastic anisotropy of MgZn2 Laves phase is dependent on the external pressure.

In order to investigate the micro-hardness of MgZn2 compound, the theoretical Vickers hardness of MgZn2 was calculated by the following relation [32]:
7
$$ H_{v} = 2 \bigl( \lambda ^{2}G \bigr)^{0.585} - 3. $$ where λ=G/B is Pugh’s modulus ratio. The calculated results are shown in Table 2. It shows that the theoretical Vickers hardness of MgZn2 is 1.80 GPa at 0 GPa, which implies that it is low stiff material. According to Eq. (6), the value of H
v is primarily determined by shear modulus. The Vickers hardness of MgZn2 increases with applied pressure, which suggests that the pressure is beneficial to the hardness of MgZn2.

The Debye temperature (Θ
D ) of materials plays an important role in the physical properties of solids, such as specific heat, thermal expansion, and elastic stiffness constants. At low temperatures, the vibration excitations arise solely from acoustic vibrations. Hence, the Debye temperature calculated from elastic constants is the same as that determined from specific heat measurements. The Debye temperature Θ
D calculated from elastic constants can be estimated from the averaged sound velocity V
m by the following equation [33]:
8
$$ \varTheta _{D} = \frac{h}{k_{B}} \biggl[ \frac{3n}{4\pi} \biggl( \frac{N_{A}\rho}{M} \biggr) \biggr]^{1/3}V_{m}. $$ where h is Planck’s constant, k
B is Boltzmann’s constant, N
A is Avogadro’s number, ρ(=M/V) is the density, M is the molecular weight, and n is the number of atoms per formula unit. The average wave velocity V
m in the polycrystalline material can be calculated by using the following equation [34]:
9
$$\begin{aligned} &{V_{m} = \biggl[ \frac{1}{3} \biggl( \frac{2}{V_{t}^{3}} + \frac{1}{V_{l}^{3}} \biggr) \biggr]^{ - 1/3},} \end{aligned}$$
10
$$\begin{aligned} &{V_{t} = \sqrt{\frac{G}{\rho}},} \end{aligned}$$
11
$$\begin{aligned} &{V_{l} = \sqrt{ \biggl( B + \frac{4}{3}G \biggr)\Big/ \rho}.} \end{aligned}$$ where B is the bulk modulus, G is the shear modulus, V
t is the transverse sound velocity, and V
l is the longitudinal sound velocity. The calculated Θ
D with a step of 5 GPa from 0 GPa to 50 GPa are listed in Table 3. The Debye temperature obtained here is 293.7 K at 0 GPa, which agrees well with the theoretical value of 259.46 K [13] and 329.9 K [35] obtained from the elastic constants and of 304 K [36] derived from the calorimetric measurements. It should be noted that the Debye temperature calculated by Chen et al. [13] using the PW91 functional is smaller with respect to our result. This is due to the smaller B and G values reported in [13] than the present calculated values. As shown in Table 3, it can be seen that Debye temperature increases with applied pressure. The effect of temperature on Debye temperature will be given in Sect. 3.4.

Section2.Heading: Electronic structure
Section2.Para:
The Mulliken analysis has been performed in order to quantitatively evaluate the effect of pressure on the bonding characteristics of MgZn2 [40]. Table 4 gives the Mulliken charge (e) and bond population of MgZn2 under pressure. The electrons transferred from Mg atoms to Zn (I) and Zn (II) atoms is 0.46e and 0.53e at 0 GPa, respectively. The calculated results show an excellent agreement when compared with the data reported in [13]. The charge transferred from Mg atoms to Zn atoms reveals the existence of ionic nature in MgZn2 crystal. As the pressure is up to 50 GPa, the absolute value of the charge transfer does also increase, which means that the ionicity interaction under high pressure becomes stronger than that under 0 GPa. It is well known that the absolute magnitudes of the atomic charges by the population analysis have little physical meaning, since they are highly sensitive to the atomic basis set [41]. However, the trends observed in the process of charge transfer under different pressure are meaningful to have a better understanding of the bonding characterization. Furthermore, the Mulliken bond population is also considered. For the bond population, the lowest and highest value implies that the chemical bond exhibits strong ionicity and covalency, respectively. The nearest-neighbor inter-atomic distances of Mg–Mg, Mg–Zn, and Zn–Zn bonds in the MgZn2 crystal are only discussed and presented in Table 4. It can be found that the Zn–Zn bonds exhibit more covalence than the other two types of bonds at 0 GPa. The ionicity interaction of Zn–Zn bonds at 50 GPa becomes stronger than that at 0 GPa. It is noted that the negative value of Mg–Zn bonds at 50 GPa represents the antibonding type interaction. The bonding characteristics of MgZn2 are a combination of metallic, covalent, and ionic nature.

Section2.Heading: Thermodynamic properties
Section2.Para:
The thermodynamic properties of crystals can be precisely determined by phonons. However, the method can be a very time-consuming process. Thus, the quasi-harmonic Debye model was applied to investigate the thermodynamic properties of MgZn2. Thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 are determined in the temperature range from 0 to 1000 K, where the quasi-harmonic Debye model remains fully valid. Meanwhile, the pressure range of 0–50 GPa also has been selected. The representative thermodynamic properties, including Debye temperature (Θ
D ), heat capacity (C
v and C
p ), thermal expansion coefficient (α), and Grüneisen parameter (γ) have been obtained. Firstly, the Θ
D of MgZn2 under various pressures as a function of temperature is investigated, as presented in the inset of Fig. 4(a). Our calculated Debye temperature is 297.5 K at 0 K and 0 GPa by using the quasi-harmonic Debye model method, which is consistent with the values reported in [13, 35, 36]. These results suggest that the thermodynamic calculations of MgZn2 in the present work are reliable. It is also observed that the Θ
D decreases smoothly with increasing temperature in low pressure, which demonstrates that the vibration frequency of the particles in MgZn2 changes with the pressure and temperature. As the pressure increases, the dependence of Θ
D at different temperatures on pressure is roughly the same with only negligible discrepancies. The current investigations demonstrate that the Θ
D shows strong pressure dependence, but weak temperature dependence. Specially, the Θ
D at high pressure (i.e., 50 GPa) exhibits independence on the temperature, as shown in Fig. 4(a).
Fig. 4
Temperature dependence of the heat capacity C
v at different pressures. Inset is the temperature dependence of the Debye temperature at various pressures (a). The differentials of special heats of MgZn2 as a function of temperature under various pressure (b)

Figure 4(a) also gives the variation of heat capacity at constant volume (C
v ) with temperature at different pressures. The current results are also compared with the values obtained from the method of phonon by Chen et al. [13]. It can be found that the curve of heat capacity of MgZn2 at 0 K and 0 GPa is similar to each other at low temperature (T<200 K). While at high temperature, the obtained values of heat capacity from the method of quasi-harmonic Debye model are larger than that of phonon. The difference can be explained by the quasi-harmonic Debye model, which considers both the effects of phonon and anharmonicity, while the effect of anharmonicity is neglected in the method of phonon. In addition, when the temperature is below than 300 K, the rise of C
v is proportional to T 3, which obeys the Debye’s law [42]. When the temperature is higher than 300 K, the C
v is independent much on temperature and converges to a constant of 74.43 J mol−1 K−1, which is close to Dulong–Petit limit (3NR), where N is the total number of atoms in the cell, and R is the ideal gas constant [43]. The present calculated heat capacity C
v is 71.43 J mol−1 K−1 at 0 GPa and 300 K, which is larger than that reported in [13]. It is difficult to evaluate the magnitude of errors between theory and experiments, since the experimental data of heat capacity cannot be found for MgZn2. Our calculated results can be served as a prediction for future investigations. In order to achieve better understanding of the heat capacity at constant volume (C
v ) and constant pressure (C
p ) under different pressures, the difference between C
v and C
p are presented in Fig. 4(b). The relationship of C
v and C
p can be found with the formula as follows [22]:
12
$$ C _{{p}} = C _{{v}} (1 + \alpha \gamma T). $$

It is shown that the value of C
P is close to the value of C
v at low temperature, and larger than that of C
v at high temperature due to the effect of thermal expansion coefficient on heat capacity. Moreover, the difference between C
v and C
p is getting smaller with applied pressure at a given temperature. It can be concluded that the effect of pressure on C
p decreases with increasing temperature.

Finally, the thermal expansion coefficient α and Grüneisen parameter γ at different temperatures as a function of pressure are illustrated in Fig. 5. The calculated thermal expansion coefficient of MgZn2 is 2.24×10−5K−1 at 0 GPa and 300 K. As shown in Fig. 5(a), the thermal expansion coefficient increases exponentially with temperature (below 300 K) at constant pressure. When the temperature is above 300 K, the thermal expansion coefficient increases linearly and then follows with a gentle slope. While at constant temperature, the thermal expansion coefficient decreases strongly with pressure. It is also shown that the effect of temperature on the thermal expansion coefficient becomes less obviously at high temperature. Figure 5(b) plots the temperature dependence of the Grüneisen parameter (γ) under different pressures. The γ can be used to describe the alteration of the vibration frequency of the crystal lattice as a result of temperature change [44]. It is obvious to observe the value of γ decreases significantly upon compression, while remaining nearly constant with the variation of temperature at high pressure. It shows the effect of temperature on γ is less than that of pressure. The results show that the pressure and the temperature have significant effects on these thermodynamic properties.
Fig. 5
The dependence of thermal expansion coefficient (a) and Grüneisen parameter (b) of MgZn2 as a function of pressure under various temperatures

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, the structural, electronic, and thermodynamic properties of MgZn2 Laves phase under pressure range from 0 to 50 GPa have been investigated by using the first-principles calculations based on DFT. It is found that the MgZn2 Laves phase is without undergoing a phase transition, and exhibits more compressible along the a direction than along the c direction. The elastic constants, polycrystalline elastic moduli, Poisson’s ratio, elastic anisotropy as well as the theoretical Vickers hardness of MgZn2 determined by using the Voigt–Reusse–Hill approximation at various pressures are successfully calculated. It is concluded that the pressure plays a significant role in mechanical properties of MgZn2. Additionally, the DOS and Mulliken analysis under high pressure have been determined in order to get some insight on the bonding characteristics of MgZn2. It is found that the peaks of the TDOS in about −8.0 eV split into some small peaks and become wider under compression, which may be attributed to the delocalization among the bonding atoms in MgZn2 crystal. Finally, the dependences of the Debye temperature, heat capacity, thermal expansion coefficient and Grüneisen parameter on pressure and temperature of MgZn2 are obtained and discussed by using the quasi-harmonic Debye model. As the pressure rises, it is found that the effect of pressure on the Debye temperature is more significant than that of temperature. The present work provides one more clearly insight into the properties of typical C14-type Laves phase MgZn2 and stimulates further experimental study on it.
